title: Which is a more fitting song for the Vietnam War, Wagner's 'Ride of the Valkyries' or the Rolling Stone's 'Gimme Shelter'? - Quora

response.answer_text: It will depend on what image you are holding in your mind-(or if you weren’t there, what scene from a movie you’re evoking) ‘Valkyries’ bring to mind a overwhelming, powerful gauntlet of airships flying toward some target of destruction. It is a long distance camera shot. ‘Shelter’ evokes a sense of impending violence, knowing something very bad is about to happen, and then provides an incendiary backdrop as the fire fight begins, and intensifies. This is an emotional close up of an uneasy soldier. But there are others- ‘Run through the jungle’ background music for a patrol, pushing into enemy territory, not knowing if or when you will be attacked, or running full speed in retreat from an unexpected ambush “Two hundred million guns are loaded …Better run through the jungle” ‘For what its worth’- anthem for the protesters/establishment conflict: “There's battle lines being drawn Nobody's right if everybody's wrong” ‘Ohio’- a chronicle of how a protest can turn into a slaughter “Four dead in Ohio” Quite a few more, like Fortunate Son, Feel like I’m fixin’ to die Rag, We Gotta Get Out of This Place, Purple haze have been cited by Vets as soundtracks to their stay in Viet Nam- BUT- Finally, a lot of folk agree that perhaps the most powerful emotions are evoked by Pete Seeger’s “Waist deep in the big muddy”- “Waist deep! Neck deep! Soon even a tall man'll be over his head, we'reWaist deep in the Big Muddy! …And the big fool says to push on!”
